meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess we had an extension extensive conversation of life on IO.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: We're looking for high risk.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Marlow
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, put up that flag. I like it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: I can take your name out of that if you want.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: I may I may say that IO probably does not support surface life. I don't know anything about these subsurface aquifer options, but um I don't know if such things exist. It seems like they would have already exploded out into space by now.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Christopher Hamilton
meeting_annotations.transcript: So aquifer being water, absolutely not. Um aquifer being composed of sulfur that um is behaving as a fluid in the subsurface much like terrestrial aquifers do with water. Yes. Um but but for the most part the indication is IO is bone dry. And I think it would be a pretty remarkable series of uh events that would allow uh IO's subsurface to remain active today. Possible, but probably very unlikely. The key point I was making is that IO could have been habitable at an earlier time when it wasn't the hellish world it is now or it could be habitable in a future time to something else that favors energy over an otherwise hostile environment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Christopher Hamilton
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, um the other point that I scribbled at one point much earlier on in the discussion is that the time is a critical factor. and I I think that when we think about habitability in extreme environments, it is useful to think about time as a component of an extreme environment. either when in a planet's history or the potential intervals between uh particularly in a planet that's undergoing a periodic or an oscillatory state where it moves from ice house to relatively favorable greenhouse, something has to be able to potentially survive that transition and so time um or dormancy or is actually a component of of habitability. It's not just the environment now but the time between those environments.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think we're down to about a minute.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Are you happy Maggie?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: So happy Tim.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: At least about this.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Happy in general. A radiant snowflake per usual.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: You said you were knocking at the door of tenure. Does that mean you're awaiting the envelope?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, I have gotten the letter but the appointments don't start until September.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh great.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess you could say I got tenure.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: There you go.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Marlow
meeting_annotations.transcript: Congratulations.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Thank you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well deserved.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Not a person who will believe it until they send me the actual signed letter.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Email from the sub Dean that says congratulations and going to do it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's awesome. Congratulations.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Marlow
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, that's great.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Amanda Stockton
meeting_annotations.transcript: My appointment doesn't technically start until August either, but I've already gotten the official letter. So I'm going to claim it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: To admit I've gotten grants until the money actually arrives. So this is just a a nature of my long-term realism.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
